column7: Typo - How can the denominative form "sumnaya" be conjugated with a long vowel? This is incorrect. The denominative form "sumnāya" is listed SEPARATELY and conjugated accordingly. Therefore, the form "sumnaya" MUST have a short vowel in all related forms. Otherwise, what is the point of a separate listing? I humbly request that Jim have a look at this.

column6: I hope that Jim will look into this and perhaps open a discussion on Github. The problem is as follows: Here we have a reference to three words: The Headword itself "vartsa" as well as "bārsva" and "vartsya". I have not been able to find any of these words located anywhere else except for this single listing in MW dictionary where nothing is defined and we are left scratching our heads wondering, "what is the point of this?"

Typo – I believe that these three words are part of the definition being offered. Therefore, the portion "Buddh." is merely an abbreviation for the word "Buddhist" and should NOT be set apart in a different Font Style from the preceding word "of" and the following word "Sūtra". I believe that the word "Buddh." is simply a modifier to the word "Sūtras". Simply put, "Buddh." should not be made to appear differently in your "scripting language" from the word "of" and the word "Sūtra". These three words are all meant to be rendered in the exact same way as a SINGLE coherent phrase. I hope that Jim will look into this correction himself.

column6: Please Add the Headword "śreḍhī". What is the point of only listing two out of the three words cited here? There is the Headword listed as "śreṭī" AND there is the Headword listed as "śreḍī". Therefore, it is unreasonable to ignore the listing of the Headword "śreḍhī" which is given equal status here with the other two words, as all three are listed together. As a further point of interest, the Apte Dictionary lists only the Headword "śreḍhī" which I am insisting needs to be included in MW dictionary. Otherwise an unreasonable inconsistency is being maintained which does not due justice to the magnificence of the Sanskrit Language. I hope that Jim will agree with my reasoning and make this correction. Thank you very much.

The reference "cf. bṛhaṭ-" being under the Headword "ṭikka" would be fully written out as "bṛhaṭṭikka". Therefore we have two possible forms which do not match: (the Headword given here) "bṛhaṭṭika" and the reference cited (under the Headword ṭikka)  as "bṛhaṭṭikka".
Typo – Please let me know if you would like to implement the proper diacritic markings for the online definitions.

Typo – Please note that the "hyphen" is required. In the printed text there is a line break, but the "hyphen" is required (nityam) because there is no such single word as "Datetree" in the english language.

column6: Place the following, "(cf. kautsa, puru-kutsa, &c.)" under [ID=52030].
column7: ID Placement Error: Please note that the printed text does not contain the ID numberings of the online version.  There are certain cases where your ID numbering system can be misleading in relation to the printed text. In this case I am proposing to move the reference "(cf. kautsa, puru-kutsa, &c.)" and place it with the above definition as part of [ID=52030]. The reason for this is that I do not believe this reference bears relation to the neuter definition of "the plant Costus speciosus".

Typo – Please note that Apte offers this correct spelling in his own dictionary under the word "śākya" with the compound formation being "śakya-muni". Therefore I suggest this correction here. If there is one problem with the Sanskrit Language it is the abundance of variant spellings, half of which are probably absolutely incorrect, but have been absorbed into the language by the force of usage. That would make a good discussion on Github.

Typo – Please note there three corrections are suggested here. The first correction is required: "idāṇāṃ"; the other two corrections are suggested because there can only be a direct relation to the word "saṃkṣāra" if it is actually being used in the parenthetical addition. Otherwise, why offer additional information that is unrelated to the Headword?
Typo – Please note that three corrections are made here which match the printed text. I consider the "comma" to be very important.

Typo – Please note that the printed text appears to approve the Causative form with both a "long" and a "short" vowel. These two forms must be included in the online edition of MW dictionary. Of course you may decide your preferred way of implementing this correction.
Typo – This follows the printed text for those with a discerning eye.

Typo – The printed text appears to confirm the feminine adjective with either a short or long vowel. Both Apte and Shabda Dictionaries show the feminine adjective as having a short vowel. I believe that we need to offer the "short vowel" as an option for the feminine adjective (especially considering the Headword itself is listed with a short vowel). Of course you may notate this correction according to your liking.
Typo – Please note as there is no such verbal root listed as "hvar", I am forced to offer two possible alternatives as the correction. I hope that Jim will look into confirming this correction.
Typo – Please note that this is a very serious error. An entire definition has been misrepresented. I am very pleased to make this correction (and it is worth 1000 points).

column5: N. of an, Up.  and an Upapurāṇa
column6: N. of an Up. and an Upapur.
column7: Typo – Please note that this correction follows the printed text. The printed text does not indicate any reason to "change the coding" as you have done in the online edition. The form "Up." and "Upapur." should remain in "the same coding" as the entire definition itself. Perhaps you prefer to deviate for some reason? I prefer to follow the printed text and keep things simple. We are not referring to "the names of some other text"; MW dictionary is simply stating a definition which happens to be the name of an Upaniṣad and an Upapurāṇa. There is no "external reference" intended here. This is also a consideration for a Global correction to the Many Many instances of this exact same sort.

column5: m. a kind of wind instrument
column7: Typo – Please note that the gender here is questionable. Apte lists this particular definition as "neuter gender". In MW dictionary the previous definition was listed as "m. or n." And this option of gender has not been "cancelled" or "restated" in any way. Therefore the gender of this particular definition should remains as "m. or n." or revert to simply "n." which was the previous gender listed. Please see the printed text. The "masculine gender" has not been specifically stated here and therefore it is an error make this assertion.

Typo – I prefer to follow the printed text and treat the definition in a pure straightforward way. To change the coding of "Buddh." seems to me unnecessary and strictly incorrect. This sort of issue occurs many times in the online MW dictionary. If there is no direct reference to another "work or text", then I maintain that the entire definition should be treated in with the same coding (font style) thereby following the printed page.
